Key ideas:

  1. The whole hight is scrollable, except BACK button (it is a mistake it's scrollable right now). Getting back to the home page is not a problem since the logo is a home button + we can provide the batch about important unreads scrolled away.
  2. We could provide a way to collapse some views the way Gmail does it with labels. Slack also does that and 1 point. Details to be designed...
  3. Right now we have 1 stream group with a name STREAM but we could provide more stream groups as a way to organize big communities/companies.

One of the key interaction questions around having multiple groups parallel to STREAMS is how to handle the filtering behavior -- right now, there's a single filter input under STREAMS, and I think that's probably what one would want, rather than one filter input per category? Not sure.

But I agree that visually, we probably want stream categories to feel like they're at the STREAMS level. Do we know how we want pinned streams to interact with stream categories? I'm not sure whether all pinned streams should be at the very top, or whether you pin within each category, or whether we try to make pinned streams appear twice, once within their category and again at the top. All of these options feel like they have downsides to trade off.

I see the appeal of having the whole region be scrollable; it feels simpler. But I worry about some of the practical implications:

  • I'm not sure it's worth a line of space for a MORE/LESS control to hide a few of the global filters, so I'd prefer we focus on other directions for that detail.
  • I'm not sure that the "^ UNREAD" indicator addresses the user story for why we want the "All messages" and "Private messages" unread counts to be always visible, which is the situational awareness, without having to click on anything, of whether you have new unread messages, and whether new ones are coming in regularly. (The "All messages" total will be more important in lower-traffic communities). I've seen other products, like Discord, that do a "More unread above/below" thing in their sidebar, and if you've got a moderate number of unreads, it kinda feels useless, because it's always there. Possibly there's a tweak on it that could address it -- like if "12 unread private messages" fit? But that may be unfun to implement around corner cases like scroll positions where part of the "private messages" section is visible.
  • I feel like "Drafts" and "private messages being accessible with a single click is fairly important to those features feeling usable; having to scroll up potentially past 50 things to get to them likely won't feel good, and I'm not sure users will intuit that clicking "^ UNREAD" is an intended way to get to drafts/recent conversations/etc.
  • We should keep in mind we're likely to add an Inbox view adjacent to Recent Topics in the sidebar, and it's probably similarly going to be something that some folks want to visit often. (I expect it to be an option for the default view, and so some users will get there via clicking the Zulip logo in the corner, but others might still have Recent Topics as their default view, for example).

Do we know how we want pinned streams to interact with stream categories?

Thinking back to my experience with channel management on Slack at my previous job, I think it's really valuable for pinned streams to be their own top section. That makes it possible to implement various kinds of "zero unreads" policies for those streams while managing your other streams in a different way. Having the stream also appear in its assigned category might be a good idea, perhaps with a setting.

One interaction that would need to be thought about if we allow having a stream appear in two places in the sidebar is how to handle the topics being opened while viewing the stream -- right now, it doesn't matter what you clicked on, if you somehow end up viewing stream foo, topic bar, then we show stream foo open in the sidebar and topic bar highlighted. Simplest would probably be to just have it appear open in both places, but I could see that feeling broken in cases where you don't have so many streams that there's a scrollbar at all. Similarly, logic to scroll so the currently selected topic is visible would need to pick which one to scroll to, etc. Not unsolvable, but a consideration for that class of design.
I think my expectation as a user would be that it should just open wherever I clicked on it.
Right, but it also opens if you click #design > UI redesign: left sidebar, and the question becomes which of the two copies opens, or do both? And which copy does it scroll you to? Etc.
Oh, I see. I think always defaulting to the pinned one (which I'm assuming will be higher in the sidebar) would work fine.

Yeah, I think a rule along those lines (basically, always open just the pinned copy unless you specifically clicked on the other one) would work, and even preserve the present invariant that only one stream can have its topics open at a time (changing that entails some implementation complexity not worth getting into unless we actually want to do so).

Yeah, stream groups is a feature that we've wanted to have for a while, but would be difficult to fit into the current left sidebar design. To talk a bit about the concrete changes in this proposal:

  • The top navigation views area will become collapsable by the user, with a custom collapsed state that has icons on it so you can still access things without expanding it in one click if you like; this is intended to balance the fact that these are very useful views but also take up a decent amount of space.
  • The current STREAMS section will become collapsible; this is mostly an irrelevant feature until we add stream group support, but in theory, stream groups would be a straightforward setting to add. There'd be an "OTHER STREAMS" section at the bottom if you have at least one stream group and not every stream is in a stream group. (I think stream groups would not be hard to start adding -- a base version would be just a data model and a dropdown in "Manage streams" for which group something is in, and we very much want them for permissions model reasons eventually).
  • Pinned streams become pinned only within their stream group. This is probably less convenient if you want to have a single place for all the streams you care about across the organization, but is likely more convenient in other settings. (Not an actual change until organizations actually have stream groups).
  • We're basically going to lose the global "filter streams" widget for organization using stream groups; instead you'll be only able to filter streams within a group, mainly because it's really not clear where to put a filter box otherwise. I think this is OK.
  • The main always-visible place for unread counts will possibly be on the stream group headings, not "All messages" or "Inbox", since the latter may be collapsed. But we can of course fiddle with this sort of detail.
Any feedback here?

In general, I'm super excited for this set of changes. :) I think the collapsible top area, with shortcut buttons in the collapsed state, solves a space vs. access to views challenge we've been pondering for a while.

OK Alya Abbott and I did a thorough look through this; I think it's very much on the right track and there's a lot of details that are working well. Here's a bunch of notes on details that I think we should tweak.

• "STREAMS MAIN" / "STREAMS LONDON" don't feel grammatical as labels for stream groups and doesn't leave much space for the variable input. I think we should just have "STREAMS" (if stream groups don't exist / are not configured in the organization) or "LONDON" -- whatever the organization typed in as the name for their stream group.
    image.png

• I really like the design choice for "MORE TOPICS" of using color; feels like it solves the puzzle of that always feeling like an out-of-place element. For "BROWSE 135 MORE STREAMS MAIN", I think it can be just "BROWSE 135 MORE STREAMS" -- no need to name the stream group (it's implied by the hierarchy and the UI it will take you to will support browsing other stream groups with few added clicks).

• The heading in "more topics" for a given stream of "STREAM TOPICS" doesn't feel right. We have "BACK TO STREAMS" today, which kinda avoids trying to title the view, and I don't think is a good solution. Maybe just "ALL TOPICS" would be OK? We could also think about renaming the button to get here to "ALL TOPICS" as well :smile:. I checked the code and it is in fact every topic that exists in the stream that you can access. Or another idea we could ponder is using "ALL TOPICS" to open the view but having just the decorated stream name be the heading row -- once it's this overlay styling, I don't feel the need to have a title row for the overlay at all. (We'd have to figure out how to place the X, but pushing the vdots in a bit might work).
    image.png

• I think we should cut the "Add a stream" button at the bottom. It's a pretty active button -- not as loud as "Send" but louder than the reply buttons. And it's redundant -- "Browser N more streams" seems like an intuitive place (and if you're on every stream, that already says "Create a stream"). And the new organization state, where your organization has just 2 streams and you're subscribed to both, your sidebar is going to look like this (well I guess the first one will say "Create a stream" too, perhaps), which I think won't feel nice:
    image.png

• What feature the "MORE STREAMS DEVELOPMENT INFRASTRUCTURE" for? Is it to hide muted and/or inactive streams?
    image.png

• I don't love the "interleaved view" icon has a rightwards-pointing trapezoid shape; that icon makes me think about that rightwards arrow/trapezoid shape when trying to understand its meaning, and I think we want something more that feels like "several varied things together" like the current (admittedly kinda weird) icon tries to convey.

• The purple background part of the hover state over \vdots feels really high emphasis for something your mouse might drift over. Click area looks right, but I prefer the color-only hover we have in main. Also is it intended that the hover/click area is extra tall for wider messages? I think it could be intended, but would generally prefer just the box around the icon itself.
    image.png
    image.png

• I don't like the "shrink on click" animation for the sidebars; having the side icons, text, and unread counts all move inwards on click feels like it draws your attention, where we in fact want to make it easy for your attention to immediately move to the actual message feed you're opening. I think the bold appearing is sufficient indication that the click worked. So I propose dropping the "shrink on click" animation for this, and conceptually I think that reasoning might apply to similar elements (E.g. a full row in a popover that might have icon, label, and keyboard UI hint).

• I think we can declare victory on the icons for 3-9 user group DMs, but I think we need a bit bigger background around the number in the 10 case, both to look a bit nicer and also to not have those look visually much smaller than the 8/9s. Could additionally consider shrinking the dots in the 7/8/9 icons if we don't want the big groups to be so huge.
    image.png

• The [ around the topics within a stream looks nice, and I think the reduced width of the hover region for topics to avoid overlapping it works well. But I think the way the hover interaction with "more topics" at the bottom doesn't look great. I think a good solution would be for the bottom of the brace to only go as far right as the top does -- the brace will be more symmetric and I think it'll fix this interaction.
    image.png

• The size ratio between the lock and hash icons feels a bit off; I'm not sure exactly what's going on but in the prototype, the lock icons feel wider/bigger in a way that feels off and in main I don't feel that way. Globes might also be a bit too big.

• When in "more topics", the interaction between the fading and the level of contrast in the unread counts make them feel kinda unreadable to me; specifics vary with theme.
    image.png

• With the larger font in the sidebar, it feels a bit cramped for horizontal space, both for topic names but also for the space between the names in label rows like VIEWS, DIRECT MESSAGES, etc. We should consider making the left sidebar a bit wider in this design pass.

(Also worth mentioning that we may want to increase the maximum length of topics from 60 characters after the design supports line-wrapping longer ones; though I think we'd still have hints in the compose box discouraging very long topics; the extra length would mainly be for topics generated by integrations like the title of a GitHub issue)

• I find it a bit difficult that the "active stream" color is identical to the "hovered stream" color (which adds a border as well). I think it's really important that if your eyes glance at the sidebar while the active conversation is visible, that it draws your attention in an unambiguous way, and having two rows that look almost the same feels like it defeats that. If we want to avoid the current design that uses different colors for those, we could try having the mouse-house behavior be just a border part, without also having the "active stream" background color? My other idea would be to have them be different shades of the same color, with the "active stream" one being higher constrast/stronger.

Another question for you, @Vlad Korobov: in working this morning on cleaning and shoring up the layout definitions in the existing left sidebar to pave the way for a smoother implementation of your new design, I was curious about the placement of icons. Here the follow icon (eyeball) sits in the same column as unreads:

Are you thinking that certain icons will just sort of stack up like that? Or will there be dedicated columns for them?

My motivation for asking is that I think it might be smarter to move from the current flex-based layouts to a grid-based layouts on the left sidebar rows. There are a few advantages to that that immediately come to mind:

  1. Items, like checkboxes or icons/indicators, can be added and removed at the DOM level without affecting the layout
  2. Especially for things like multi-line topic names and DM groups, we might have better control over the vertical alignment of different elements
  3. The columns of each row can be more precisely sized and controlled at the container level (using things like minmax()) without having to dive into individual children and make different declarations for the flex grow, shrink, and basis properties.

I should add that my thinking about this is sort of top-level for each row. Certain elements, like the username/status emoji for one-to-one DMs, would be described as flexboxes. But anywhere we could basically draw a vertical line down the design seems to me to be a candidate for grid.
